instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: Ok so I'm stumped, and I'm sure it may be something dumb I'm overlooking, but this board came in with liquid around the SMC, clock chip, and a backlight chip. Cleaned areas of corrosion no problem nothing concerned me that much. Currently getting no light on the charger and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is on fire. I removed it and the diode to 3v42 to check for a short on input. I got no short but said what the hell and replaced the 3 input caps and 3v42 regulator to be safe. <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> remains on fire. I next thought possibly <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and the ISL could be causing it so removed both and still no change <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire. What else can be causing this resistor to burn? No short on 3v42 or <SIGNAL>PPVIN_PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. No short on PPBUS. I'm out of ideas all help is appreciated.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted btw 16 volts on source 6.86 volts on gate.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message:
Diode mode on L7095?
Remove <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> and apply voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7092</CAPACITOR>, check what gets hot....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message:
.29 on L7095 both pins.
Removed diode and put power through the regulator got hot again. Removed now zero amp pull as opposed to .11 amps pulled before. Going to put one more new regulator on and hope for the best.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: No change <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> still smoking even with new regulator. Have tried 4 regulators now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: Also when <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is removed, the pads it sits on do not get hot, so I don't think there's an internal short under it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message:
Remove clock chip and SMC. They could be overloading the 3V42 rail without causing a short.

Actually inject voltage into 3V42 line first and monitor current draw. SMC or clock getting warm?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: Thanks Duke! Will do my guess is that the clock chip will be doing it, but I will let you know when I get to it today

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire no matter what.
threads.message: Bad clock chip was the issue. Once it was removed no more <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> on fire and green light came back. Put the ISL back with a new (donor board because my new spool might be bad) clock chip and all is good! Thanks again Duke!
